rev.diff:
Line 63: Line 63:
On June 7, 2011, an electrical component in a switcher room caused a small fire with poisonous gases and Halon extinguisher activation which forced a partial evacuation.<ref>{{Cite news|last= Tracy|first=Ryan| title = Nebraska Nuclear Plant Lost Cooling System After Fire | newspaper = Wall Street Journal| location = Omaha, Nebraska| date = June 8, 2011| url = http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052702304778304576374011963022284.html|accessdate = 2011-06-16}}</ref> The fire was no longer active when firefighters arrived and according to officials, the public was never in any danger, however in response, the Omaha Public Power District declared an Alert<ref>{{Cite web| title = NRC: Event Notification Report for June 8, 2011| publisher = Nuclear regulatory Commission| date = June 7, 2011| url = http://www.nrc.gov/reading-rm/doc-collections/event-status/event/2011/20110608en.html#en46932| accessdate = 2011-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=NRC: Emergency Classification|url=http://www.nrc.gov/about-nrc/emerg-preparedness/about-emerg-preparedness/emerg-classification.html|publisher=Nuclear Regulatory Comission|accessdate=19 June 2011}}</ref> (second level on a [[Nuclear_safety_in_the_United_States#Emergency_Classifications|4 level taxonomy]]). The fire impacted a pump which is used to recirculate coolant water through the spent fuel pool. The pump was offline for an hour but backup equipment was not needed as the estimated time for the pool to reach boiling temperature was over 88 hours.<ref>{{Cite news|last= Cole|first=Kevin| title =Nuke Plant Lost Spent Fuel Pump In Suspected Fire| newspaper = KETV news| location = Omaha, Nebraska| date = June 8, 2011| url = http://www.ketv.com/news/28172754/detail.html | accessdate = 2011-06-08}}</ref> The evacuation was the first at the facility since 1992, when {{convert|20000|USgal}} (ca. 76 [[Tonne|t]]) of coolant leaked into a containment building from the reactor.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Smoke Causes Scare At Nuclear Plant| newspaper = KETV news| location = Omaha, Nebraska| publisher = Hearst| date = June 7, 2011| url = http://www.ketv.com/news/28163138/detail.html| accessdate = 2011-06-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last= Cole|first=Kevin| title = Smoke triggers nuclear plant alarm| newspaper = Omaha World-Herald| location = Omaha, Nebraska| date = June 7, 2011| url = http://www.omaha.com/article/20110607/NEWS01/110609814/0#smoke-triggers-nuclear-plant-alarm | accessdate = 2011-06-07}}</ref>
On June 7, 2011, an electrical component in a switcher room caused a small fire with poisonous gases and Halon extinguisher activation which forced a partial evacuation.<ref>{{Cite news|last= Tracy|first=Ryan| title = Nebraska Nuclear Plant Lost Cooling System After Fire | newspaper = Wall Street Journal| location = Omaha, Nebraska| date = June 8, 2011| url = http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052702304778304576374011963022284.html|accessdate = 2011-06-16}}</ref> The fire was no longer active when firefighters arrived and according to officials, the public was never in any danger, however in response, the Omaha Public Power District declared an Alert<ref>{{Cite web| title = NRC: Event Notification Report for June 8, 2011| publisher = Nuclear regulatory Commission| date = June 7, 2011| url = http://www.nrc.gov/reading-rm/doc-collections/event-status/event/2011/20110608en.html#en46932| accessdate = 2011-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=NRC: Emergency Classification|url=http://www.nrc.gov/about-nrc/emerg-preparedness/about-emerg-preparedness/emerg-classification.html|publisher=Nuclear Regulatory Comission|accessdate=19 June 2011}}</ref> (second level on a [[Nuclear_safety_in_the_United_States#Emergency_Classifications|4 level taxonomy]]). The fire impacted a pump which is used to recirculate coolant water through the spent fuel pool. The pump was offline for an hour but backup equipment was not needed as the estimated time for the pool to reach boiling temperature was over 88 hours.<ref>{{Cite news|last= Cole|first=Kevin| title =Nuke Plant Lost Spent Fuel Pump In Suspected Fire| newspaper = KETV news| location = Omaha, Nebraska| date = June 8, 2011| url = http://www.ketv.com/news/28172754/detail.html | accessdate = 2011-06-08}}</ref> The evacuation was the first at the facility since 1992, when {{convert|20000|USgal}} (ca. 76 [[Tonne|t]]) of coolant leaked into a containment building from the reactor.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Smoke Causes Scare At Nuclear Plant| newspaper = KETV news| location = Omaha, Nebraska| publisher = Hearst| date = June 7, 2011| url = http://www.ketv.com/news/28163138/detail.html| accessdate = 2011-06-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last= Cole|first=Kevin| title = Smoke triggers nuclear plant alarm| newspaper = Omaha World-Herald| location = Omaha, Nebraska| date = June 7, 2011| url = http://www.omaha.com/article/20110607/NEWS01/110609814/0#smoke-triggers-nuclear-plant-alarm | accessdate = 2011-06-07}}</ref>
â   â
==News Blackout Stories==
  â
A Pakastani news source has reported that the U.S. has ordered a "news blackout" on stories surrounding negatively impacting events of the reactor.<ref>http://nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/International/18-Jun-2011/US-orders-news-blackout-over-crippled-Nebraska-Nuclear-Plant-report</ref> See story [http://nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/International/18-Jun-2011/US-orders-news-blackout-over-crippled-Nebraska-Nuclear-Plant-report here]. Other stories are also circulating around the internet that mention this.<ref>http://www.huntingtonnews.net/5415</ref>. A google search on "fort calhoun nuclear news blackout" reveals numerous stories throughout the internet.<ref>http://www.google.com/search?source=ig&hl=en&rlz=&=&q=fort+calhoun+nuclear&aq=0&aqi=g10&aql=&oq=fort+calhou#sclient=psy&hl=en&biw=1336&bih=756&source=hp&q=fort+calhoun+nuclear+news+blackout&aq=f&aqi=&aql=&oq=&pbx=1&bav=on.2,or.r_gc.r_pw.&fp=951dc7972bfd90fb</ref>
  â   â
One site mentions that the Omaha Herald did NOT send in local reporters to report on the story.<ref>http://sgtreport.com/2011/06/fort-calhoun-rising-water-falling-journalism</ref>. The article states that many news agencies simply regurgitate the "OPPD press release announcing a low-level emergency". The Omaha article can be found [http://owh.com/article/20110527/NEWS01/705279816/10312874 here].<ref>[http://owh.com/article/20110527/NEWS01/705279816/10312874 Rising river brings precautions]</ref>
  â   â
Another [http://wtpotus.wordpress.com/2011/06/20/obama-ordered-news-blackout-on-nebraska-nuclear-power-plant-meltdown/ site] has a disclaimer that reads: "Disclaimer: Sorcha Faal, the nom de plume (alias/penname) of David Booth, always writes intriguing conspiracy news stories that are full of speculation and usually have no viable sources. Yet this article is filled with sources for his information. Except, as yet , no source for the information coming from Russiaâs Federal Atomic Energy Agency has been located; so this information can not be verified through another news source."<ref>http://wtpotus.wordpress.com/2011/06/20/obama-ordered-news-blackout-on-nebraska-nuclear-power-plant-meltdown</ref>
  â   â
There is another [http://sgtreport.com/2011/06/fort-calhoun-rising-water-falling-journalism/ news article] entitled: "Fort Calhoun: Rising Water, Falling Journalism" which discusses this further.<ref>http://sgtreport.com/2011/06/fort-calhoun-rising-water-falling-journalism</ref>
